verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:1
verses.text: The Divine Institutes Book : Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:2
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:3
verses.text: —A Comparison of the Truth with Eloquence: Why the Philosophers Did Not Attain to It.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:4
verses.text: Of the Simple Style of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:5
verses.text: Since it is supposed that the truth still lies hidden in obscurity—either through the error and ignorance of the common people, who are the slaves of various and foolish superstitions, or through the philosophers, who by the perverseness of their minds confuse rather than throw light upon it—I could wish that the power of eloquence had fallen to my lot, though not such as it was in Marcus Tullius, for that was extraordinary and admirable, but in some degree approaching it; that, being supported as much by the strength of talent as it has weight by its own force, the truth might at length come forth, and having dispelled and refuted public errors, and the errors of those who are considered wise, might introduce among the human race a brilliant light.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:6
verses.text: And I could wish that this were so, for two reasons: either that men might more readily believe the truth when adorned with embellishments, since they even believe falsehood, being captivated by the adornment of speech and the enticement of words; or, at all events, that the philosophers themselves might be overpowered by us, most of all by their own arms, in which they are accustomed to pride themselves and to place confidence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:7
verses.text: But since God has willed this to be the nature of the case, that simple and undisguised truth should be more clear, because it has sufficient ornament of itself, and on this account it is corrupted when embellished with adornings from without, but that falsehood should please by means of a splendour not its own, because being corrupt of itself it vanishes and melts away, unless it is set off and polished with decoration sought from another source; I bear it with equanimity that a moderate degree of talent has been granted to me.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:8
verses.text: But it is not in reliance upon eloquence, but upon the truth, that I have undertaken this work,—a work, perhaps, too great to be sustained by my strength; which, however, even if I should fail, the truth itself will complete, with the assistance of God, whose office this is.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:9
verses.text: For when I know that the greatest orators have often been overcome by pleaders of moderate ability, because the power of truth is so great that it defends itself even in small things by its own clearness: why should I imagine that it will be overwhelmed in a cause of the greatest importance by men who are ingenious and eloquent, as I admit, but who speak false things; and not that it should appear bright and illustrious, if not by our speech, which is very feeble, and flows from a slight fountain, but by its own light? Nor, if there have been philosophers worthy of admiration on account of their literary erudition, should I also yield to them the knowledge and learning of the truth, which no one can attain to by reflection or disputation.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:10
verses.text: Nor do I now disparage the pursuit of those who wished to know the truth, because God has made the nature of man most desirous of arriving at the truth; but I assert and maintain this against them, that the effect did not follow their honest and well-directed will, because they neither knew what was true in itself, nor how, nor where, nor with what mind it is to be sought.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:11
verses.text: And thus, while they desire to remedy the errors of men, they have become entangled in snares and the greatest errors.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:12
verses.text: I have therefore been led to this task of refuting philosophy by the very order of the subject which I have undertaken.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:13
verses.text: For since all error arises either from false religion or from wisdom, in refuting error it is necessary to overthrow both.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:14
verses.text: For inasmuch as it has been handed down to us in the sacred writings that the thoughts of philosophers are foolish, this very thing is to be proved by fact and by arguments, that no one, induced by the honourable name of wisdom, or deceived by the splendour of empty eloquence, may prefer to give credence to human rather than to divine things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:15
verses.text: Which things, indeed, are related in a concise and simple manner.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:16
verses.text: For it was not befitting that, when God was speaking to man, He should confirm His words by arguments, as though He would not otherwise be regarded with confidence: but, as it was right, He spoke as the mighty Judge of all things, to whom it belongs not to argue, but to pronounce sentence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:17
verses.text: He Himself, as God, is truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:18
verses.text: But we, since we have divine testimony for everything, will assuredly show by how much surer arguments truth may be defended, when even false things are so defended that they are accustomed to appear true.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:19
verses.text: Wherefore there is no reason why we should give so much honour to philosophers as to fear their eloquence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:20
verses.text: For they might speak well as men of learning; but they could not speak truly, because they had not learned the truth from Him in whose power it was.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:21
verses.text: Nor, indeed, shall we effect anything great in convicting them of ignorance, which they themselves very often confess.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 1:22
verses.text: Since they are not believed in that one point alone in which alone they ought to have been believed, I will endeavour to show that they never spoke so truly as when they uttered their opinion respecting their own ignorance.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:2
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:3
verses.text: —Of Philosophy, and How Vain Was Its Occupation in Setting Forth the Truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:4
verses.text: Now, since the falsehood of superstitions has been shown in the two former books, and the origin itself of the whole error has been set forth, it is the business of this book to show the emptiness and falsehood of philosophy also, that, all error being removed, the truth may be brought to light and become manifest.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:5
verses.text: Let us begin, therefore, from the common name of philosophy, that when the head itself is destroyed, an easier approach may be open to us for demolishing the whole body; if indeed that can be called a body, the parts and members of which are at variance with one another, and are not united together by any connecting link, but, as it were, dispersed and scattered, appear to palpitate rather than to live.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:6
verses.text: Philosophy is (as the name indicates, and they themselves define it) the love of wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:7
verses.text: By what argument, then, can I prove that philosophy is not wisdom, rather than by that derived from the meaning of the name itself? For he who devotes himself to wisdom is manifestly not yet wise, but devotes himself to the subject that he may be wise.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:8
verses.text: In the other arts it appears what this devotedness effects, and to what it tends: for when any one by learning has attained to these, he is now called, not a devoted follower of the profession, but an artificer.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:9
verses.text: But it is said it was on account of modesty that they called themselves devoted to wisdom, and not wise.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:10
verses.text: Nay, in truth, Pythagoras, who first invented this name, since he had a little more wisdom than those of early times, who regarded themselves as wise, understood that it was impossible by any human study to attain to wisdom, and therefore that a perfect name ought not to be applied to an incomprehensible and imperfect subject.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:11
verses.text: And, therefore, when he was asked what was his profession, he answered that he was a philosopher, that is, a searcher after wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:12
verses.text: If, therefore, philosophy searches after wisdom, it is not wisdom itself, because it must of necessity be one thing which searches, and another which is searched for; nor is the searching itself correct, because it can find nothing.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:13
verses.text: But I am not prepared to concede even that philosophers are devoted to the pursuit of wisdom, because by that pursuit there is no attaining to wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:14
verses.text: For if the power of finding the truth were connected with this pursuit, and if this pursuit were a kind of road to wisdom, it would at length be found.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:15
verses.text: But since so much time and talent have been wasted in the search for it, and it has not yet been gained, it is plain that there is no wisdom there.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:16
verses.text: Therefore they who apply themselves to philosophy do not devote themselves to the pursuit of wisdom; but they themselves imagine that they do so, because they know not where that is which they are searching for, or of what character it is.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:17
verses.text: Whether, therefore, they devote themselves to the pursuit of wisdom or not, they are not wise, because that can never be discovered which is either sought in an improper manner, or not sought at all.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 2:18
verses.text: Let us look to this very thing, whether it is possible for anything to be discovered by this kind of pursuit, or nothing.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:2
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:3
verses.text: —Of What Subjects Philosophy Consists, and Who Was the Chief Founder of the Academic Sect.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:4
verses.text: Philosophy appears to consist of two subjects, knowledge and conjecture, and of nothing more.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:5
verses.text: Knowledge cannot come from the understanding, nor be apprehended by thought; because to have knowledge in oneself as a peculiar property does not belong to man, but to God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:6
verses.text: But the nature of mortals does not receive knowledge, except that which comes from without.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:7
verses.text: For on this account the divine intelligence has opened the eyes and ears and other senses in the body, that by these entrances knowledge might flow through to the mind.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:8
verses.text: For to investigate or wish to know the causes of natural things,—whether the sun is as great as it appears to be, or is many times greater than the whole of this earth; also whether the moon be spherical or concave; and whether the stars are fixed to the heaven, or are borne with free course through the air; of what magnitude the heaven itself is, of what material it is composed; whether it is at rest and immoveable, or is turned round with incredible swiftness; how great is the thickness of the earth, or on what foundations it is poised and suspended,—to wish to comprehend these things, I say, by disputation and conjectures, is as though we should wish to discuss what we may suppose to be the character of a city in some very remote country, which we have never seen, and of which we have heard nothing more than the name.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:9
verses.text: If we should claim to ourselves knowledge in a matter of this kind, which cannot be known, should we not appear to be mad, in venturing to affirm that in which we may be refuted? How much more are they to be judged mad and senseless, who imagine that they know natural things, which cannot be known by man! Rightly therefore did Socrates, and the Academics who followed him, take away knowledge, which is not the part of a disputant, but of a diviner.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:10
verses.text: It remains that there is in philosophy conjecture only; for that from which knowledge is absent, is entirely occupied by conjecture.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:11
verses.text: For every one conjectures that of which he is ignorant.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:12
verses.text: But they who discuss natural subjects, conjecture that they are as they discuss them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:13
verses.text: Therefore they do not know the truth, because knowledge is concerned with that which is certain, conjecture with the uncertain.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:14
verses.text: Let us return to the example before mentioned.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:15
verses.text: Come, let us conjecture about the state and character of that city which is unknown to us in all respects except in name.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:16
verses.text: It is probable that it is situated on a plain, with walls of stone, lofty buildings, many streets, magnificent and highly adorned temples.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:17
verses.text: Let us describe, if you please, the customs and deportment of the citizens.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:18
verses.text: But when we shall have described these, another will make opposite statements; and when he also shall have concluded, a third will arise, and others after him; and they will make very different conjectures to those of ours.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:19
verses.text: Which therefore of all is more true? Perhaps none of them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:20
verses.text: But all things have been mentioned which the nature of the circumstances admits, so that some one of them must necessarily be true.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:21
verses.text: But it will not be known who has spoken the truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:22
verses.text: It may possibly be that all have in some degree erred in their description, and that all have in some degree attained to the truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:23
verses.text: Therefore we are foolish if we seek this by disputation; for some one may present himself who may deride our conjectures, and esteem us as mad, since we wish to conjecture the character of that which we do not know.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:24
verses.text: But it is unnecessary to go in quest of remote cases, from which perhaps no one may come to refute us.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:25
verses.text: Come, let us conjecture what is now going on in the forum, what in the senate-house.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:26
verses.text: That also is too distant.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:27
verses.text: Let us say what is taking place with the interposition of a single wall; no one can know this but he who has heard or seen it.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:28
verses.text: No one therefore ventures to say this, because he will immediately be refuted not by words, but by the presence of the fact itself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:29
verses.text: But this is the very thing which philosophers do, who discuss what is taking place in heaven, but think that they do that with impunity, because there is no one to refute their errors.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:30
verses.text: But if they were to think that some one was about to descend who would prove them to be mad and false, they would never discuss those subjects at all which they cannot possibly know.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 3:31
verses.text: Nor, however, is their shamelessness and audacity to be regarded as more successful because they are not refuted; for God refutes them to whom alone the truth is known, although He may seem to connive at their conduct, and He reckons such wisdom of men as the greatest folly.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:2
verses.text: IV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:3
verses.text: —That Knowledge is Taken Away by Socrates, and Conjecture by Zeno.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:4
verses.text: Zeno and the Stoics, then, were right in repudiating conjecture.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:5
verses.text: For to conjecture that you know that which you do not know, is not the part of a wise, but rather of a rash and foolish man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:6
verses.text: Therefore if nothing can be known, as Socrates taught, or ought to be conjectured, as Zeno taught, philosophy is entirely removed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:7
verses.text: Why should I say that it is not only overthrown by these two, who were the chiefs of philosophy, but by all, so that it now appears to have been long ago destroyed by its own arms? Philosophy has been divided into many sects; and they all entertain various sentiments.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:8
verses.text: In which do we place the truth? It certainly cannot be in all.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:9
verses.text: Let us point out some one; it follows that all the others will be without wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:10
verses.text: Let us pass through them separately; in the same manner, whatever we shall give to one we shall take away from the others.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:11
verses.text: For each particular sect overturns all others, to confirm itself and its own doctrines: nor does it allow wisdom to any other, lest it should confess that it is itself foolish; but as it takes away others, so is it taken away itself by all others.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:12
verses.text: For they are nevertheless philosophers who accuse it of folly.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:13
verses.text: Whatever sect you shall praise and pronounce true, that is censured by philosophers as false.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:14
verses.text: Shall we therefore believe one which praises itself and its doctrine, or the many which blame the ignorance of each other? That must of necessity be better which is held by great numbers, than that which is held by one only.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:15
verses.text: For no one can rightly judge concerning himself, as the renowned poet testifies; for the nature of men is so arranged, that they see and distinguish the affairs of others better than their own.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:16
verses.text: Since, therefore, all things are uncertain, we must either believe all or none: if we are to believe no one, then the wise have no existence, because while they separately affirm different things they think themselves wise; if all, it is equally true that there are no wise men, because all deny the wisdom of each individually.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:17
verses.text: Therefore all are in this manner destroyed; and as those fabled sparti of the poets, so these men mutually slay one another, so that no one remains of all; which happens on this account, because they have a sword, but have no shield.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:18
verses.text: If, therefore, the sects individually are convicted of folly by the judgment of many sects, it follows that all are found to be vain and empty; and thus philosophy consumes and destroys itself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:19
verses.text: And since Arcesilas the founder of the Academy understood this, he collected together the mutual censures of all, and the confession of ignorance made by distinguished philosophers, and armed himself against all.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:20
verses.text: Thus he established a new philosophy of not philosophizing.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:21
verses.text: From this founder, therefore, there began to be two kinds of philosophy: one the old one, which claims to itself knowledge; the other a new one, opposed to the former, and which detracts from it.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:22
verses.text: Between these two kinds of philosophy I see that there is disagreement, and as it were civil war.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:23
verses.text: On which side shall we place wisdom, which cannot be torn asunder? If the nature of things can be known, this troop of recruits will perish; if it cannot, the veterans will be destroyed: if they shall be equal, nevertheless philosophy, the guide of all, will still perish, because it is divided; for nothing can be opposed to itself without its own destruction.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:24
verses.text: But if, as I have shown, there can be no inner and peculiar knowledge in man on account of the frailty of the human condition, the party of Arcesilas prevails.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 4:25
verses.text: But not even will this stand firm, because it cannot be the case that nothing at all is known.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:2
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:3
verses.text: —That the Knowledge of Many Things is Necessary.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:4
verses.text: For there are many things which nature itself, and frequent use, and the necessity of life, compel us to know.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:5
verses.text: Accordingly you must perish, unless you know what things are useful for life, in order that you may seek them; and what are dangerous, that you may shun and avoid them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:6
verses.text: Moreover, there are many things which experience finds out.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:7
verses.text: For the various courses of the sun and moon, and the motions of the stars, and the computation of times, have been discovered, and the nature of bodies, and the strength of herbs by students of medicine, and by the cultivators of the land the nature of soils, and signs of future rains and tempests have been collected.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:8
verses.text: In short, there is no art which is not dependent on knowledge.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:9
verses.text: Therefore Arcesilas ought, if he had any wisdom, to have distinguished the things which were capable of being known, and those which were incapable.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:10
verses.text: But if he had done this, he would have reduced himself to the common herd.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:11
verses.text: For the common people have sometimes more wisdom, because they are only so far wise as is necessary.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:12
verses.text: And if you inquire of them whether they know anything or nothing, they will say that they know the things which they know, and will confess that they are ignorant of what they are ignorant.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:13
verses.text: He was right, therefore, in taking away the systems of others, but he was not right in laying the foundations of his own.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:14
verses.text: For ignorance of all things cannot be wisdom, the peculiar property of which is knowledge.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:15
verses.text: And thus, when he overcame the philosophers, and taught that they knew nothing, he himself also lost the name of philosopher, because his system is to know nothing.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 5:16
verses.text: For he who blames others because they are ignorant, ought himself to have knowledge; but when he knows nothing, what perverseness or what insolence it is, to constitute himself a philosopher on account of that very thing for which he takes away the others! For it is in their power to answer thus: If you convict us of knowing nothing, and therefore of being unwise because we know nothing, does it follow that you are not wise, because you confess that you know nothing? What progress, therefore, did Arcesilas make, except that, having despatched all the philosophers, he pierced himself also with the same sword?.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:2
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:3
verses.text: —Of Wisdom, and the Academics, and Natural Philosophy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:4
verses.text: Does wisdom therefore nowhere exist? Yes, indeed, it was amongst them, but no one saw it.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:5
verses.text: Some thought that all things could be known: these were manifestly not wise.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:6
verses.text: Others thought that nothing could be known; nor indeed were these wise: the former, because they attributed too much to man; the latter, because they attributed too little.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:7
verses.text: A limit was wanting to each on either side.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:8
verses.text: Where, then, is wisdom? It consists in thinking neither that you know all things, which is the property of God; nor that you are ignorant of all things, which is the part of a beast.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:9
verses.text: For it is something of a middle character which belongs to man, that is, knowledge united and combined with ignorance.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:10
verses.text: Knowledge in us is from the soul, which has its origin from heaven; ignorance from the body, which is from the earth: whence we have something in common with God, and with the animal creation.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:11
verses.text: Thus, since we are composed of these two elements, the one of which is endowed with light, the other with darkness, a part of knowledge is given to us, and a part of ignorance.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:12
verses.text: Over this bridge, so to speak, we may pass without any danger of falling; for all those who have inclined to either side, either towards the left hand or the right, have fallen.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:13
verses.text: But I will say how each part has erred.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:14
verses.text: The Academics argued from obscure subjects, against the natural philosophers, that there was no knowledge; and satisfied with the examples of a few incomprehensible subjects, they embraced ignorance as though they had taken away the whole of knowledge, because they had taken it away in part.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:15
verses.text: But natural philosophers, on the other hand, derived their argument from those things which are open, and inferred that all things could be known, and, satisfied with things which were manifest, retained knowledge; as if they had defended it altogether, because they had defended it in part.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:16
verses.text: And thus neither the one saw what was clear, nor the others what was obscure; but each party, while they contended with the greatest ardour either to retain or to take away knowledge only, did not see that there would be placed in the middle that which might guide them to wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:17
verses.text: But Arcesilas, who teaches that there is no knowledge, when he was detracting from Zeno, the chief of the Stoics, that he might altogether overthrow philosophy on the authority of Socrates, undertook this opinion to affirm that nothing could be known.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:18
verses.text: And thus he disproved the judgment of the philosophers, who had thought that the truth was drawn forth, and found out by their talents,—namely, because that wisdom was mortal, and, having been instituted a few ages before, had now attained to its greatest increase, so that it was now necessarily growing old and perishing, the Academy suddenly arose, the old age, as it were, of philosophy, which might despatch it now withering.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:19
verses.text: And Arcesilas rightly saw that they are arrogant, or rather foolish, who imagine that the knowledge of the truth can be arrived at by conjecture.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:20
verses.text: But no one can refute one speaking falsely, unless he who shall have previously known what is true; but Arcesilas, endeavouring to do this without a knowledge of the truth, introduced a kind of philosophy which we may call unstable or inconstant.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:21
verses.text: For, that nothing may be known, it is necessary that something be known.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:22
verses.text: For if you know nothing at all, the very knowledge that nothing can be known will be taken away.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:23
verses.text: Therefore he who pronounces as a sentiment that nothing is known, professes, as it were, some conclusion already arrived at and known: therefore it is possible for something to be known.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:24
verses.text: Of a similar character to this is that which is accustomed to be proposed in the schools as an example of the kind of fallacy called asystaton; that some one had dreamt that he should not believe dreams.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:25
verses.text: For if he did believe them, then it follows that he ought not to believe them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:26
verses.text: But if he did not believe them, then it follows that he ought to believe them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:27
verses.text: Thus, if nothing can be known, it is necessary that this fact must be known, that nothing is known.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:28
verses.text: But if it is known that nothing can be known, the statement that nothing can be known must as a consequence be false.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:29
verses.text: Thus there is introduced a tenet opposed to itself, and destructive of itself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:30
verses.text: But the evasive man wished to take away learning from the other philosophers, that he might conceal it at his home.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:31
verses.text: For truly he is not for taking it from himself who affirms anything that he may take it from others: but he does not succeed; for it shows itself, and betrays its plunderer.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:32
verses.text: How much more wisely and truly he would act, if he should make an exception, and say that the causes and systems of heavenly things only, or natural things, because they are hidden, cannot be known, for there is no one to teach them; and ought not to be inquired into, for they cannot be found out by inquiry! For if he had brought forward this exception, he would both have admonished the natural philosophers not to search into those things which exceeded the limit of human reflection; and would have freed himself from the ill-will arising from calumny, and would certainly have left us something to follow.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:33
verses.text: But now, since he has drawn us back from following others, that we may not wish to know more than we are capable of knowing, he has no less drawn us back from himself also.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 6:34
verses.text: For who would wish to labour lest he should know anything? or to undertake learning of this kind that he may even lose ordinary knowledge? For if this learning exists, it must necessarily consist of knowledge; if it does not exist, who is so foolish as to think that that is worthy of being learned, in which either nothing is learned, or something is even unlearned? Wherefore, if all things cannot be known, as the natural philosophers thought, nor nothing, as the Academics taught, philosophy is altogether extinguished.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:2
verses.text: VII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:3
verses.text: —Of Moral Philosophy, and the Chief Good.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:4
verses.text: Let us now pass to the other part of philosophy, which they themselves call moral, in which is contained the method of the whole of philosophy, since in natural philosophy there is only delight, in this there is utility also.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:5
verses.text: And since it is more dangerous to commit a fault in arranging the condition of life and in forming the character, greater diligence must be used, that we may know how we ought to live.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:6
verses.text: For in the former subject some indulgence may be granted: for whether they say anything, they bestow no advantage; or if they foolishly rave, they do no injury.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:7
verses.text: But in this subject there is no room for difference of opinion, none for error.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:8
verses.text: All must entertain the same sentiments, and philosophy itself must give instructions as it were with one mouth; because if any error shall be committed, life is altogether overthrown.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:9
verses.text: In that former part, as there is less danger, so there is more difficulty; because the obscurity of the subject compels us to entertain different and various opinions.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:10
verses.text: But in this, as there is more danger, so there is less difficulty; because the very use of the subjects and daily experiments are able to teach what is truer and better.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:11
verses.text: Let us see, therefore, whether they agree, or what assistance they give us for the better guidance of life.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:12
verses.text: It is not necessary to enlarge on every point; let us select one, and especially that which is the chief and principal thing, in which the whole of wisdom centres and depends.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:13
verses.text: Epicurus deems that the chief good consists in pleasure of mind, Aristippus in pleasure of the body.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:14
verses.text: Callipho and Dinomachus united virtue with pleasure, Diodorus with the privation of pain, Hieronymus placed the chief good in the absence of pain; the Peripatetics, again, in the goods of the mind, the body, and fortune.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:15
verses.text: The chief good of Herillus is knowledge; that of Zeno, to live agreeably to nature; that of certain Stoics, to follow virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:16
verses.text: Aristotle placed the chief good in integrity and virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:17
verses.text: These are the sentiments of nearly all.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:18
verses.text: In such a difference of opinions, whom do we follow? whom do we believe? All are of equal authority.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:19
verses.text: If we are able to select that which is better, it follows that philosophy is not necessary for us; because we are already wise, inasmuch as we judge respecting the opinions of the wise.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 7:20
verses.text: But since we come for the sake of learning wisdom, how can we judge, who have not yet begun to be wise? especially when the Academic is close at hand, to draw us back by the cloak, and forbid us to believe any one, without bringing forward that which we may follow.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:2
verses.text: VIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:3
verses.text: —Of the Chief Good, and the Pleasures of the Soul and Body, and of Virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:4
verses.text: What then remains, but that we leave raving and obstinate wranglers, and come to the judge, who is in truth the giver of simple and calm wisdom? which is able not only to mould us, and lead us into the way, but also to pass an opinion on the controversies of those men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:5
verses.text: This teaches us what is the true and highest good of man; but before I begin to speak on this subject, all those opinions must be refuted, that it may appear that no one of those philosophers was wise.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:6
verses.text: Since the inquiry is respecting the duty of man, the chief good of the chief animal ought to be placed in that which it cannot have in common with the other animals.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:7
verses.text: But as teeth are the peculiar property of wild beasts, horns of cattle, and wings of birds, so something peculiar to himself ought to be attributed to man, without which he would lose the fixed order of his condition.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:8
verses.text: For that which is given to all for the purpose of life or generation, is indeed a natural good; but still it is not the greatest, unless it be peculiar to each class.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:9
verses.text: Therefore he was not a wise man who believed that pleasure of the mind is the chief good, since that, whether it be freedom from anxiety or joy, is common to all.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:10
verses.text: I do not consider Aristippus even worthy of an answer; for since he is always rushing into pleasures of the body, and is only the slave of sensual indulgences, no one can regard him as a man: for he lived in such a manner that there was no difference between him and a brute, except this only, that he had the faculty of speech.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:11
verses.text: But if the power of speaking were given to the ass, or the dog, or swine, and you were to inquire from these why they so furiously pursue the females, that they can scarcely be separated from them, and even neglect their food and I drink; why they either drive away other males, or do not abstain from the pursuit even when vanquished, but often, when bruised by stronger animals, they are more determined in their pursuit; why they dread neither rain nor cold; why they undertake labour, and do not shrink from danger;—what other answer will they give, but that the chief good is bodily pleasure?—that they eagerly seek it, in order that they may be affected with the most agreeable sensations; and that these are of so much importance, that, for the sake of attaining them, they imagine that no labour, nor wounds, nor death itself, ought to be refused by them? Shall we then seek precepts of living from these men, who have no other feelings than those of the irrational creatures?  The Cyrenaics say that virtue itself is to be praised on this account, because it is productive of pleasure.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:12
verses.text: True, says the filthy dog, or the swine wallowing in the mire.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:13
verses.text: For it is on this account that I contend with my adversary with the utmost exertion of strength, that my valour may procure for me pleasure; of which I must necessarily be deprived if I shall come off vanquished.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:14
verses.text: Shall we therefore learn wisdom from these men, who differ from cattle and the brutes, not in feeling, but in language? To regard the absence of pain as the chief good, is not indeed the part of Peripatetic and Stoic, but of clinical philosophers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:15
verses.text: For who would not imagine that the discussion was carried on by those who were ill, and under the influence of some pain? What is so ridiculous, as to esteem that the chief good which the physician is able to give? We must therefore feel pain in order that we may enjoy good; and that, too, severely and frequently, that afterwards the absence of pain may be attended with greater pleasure.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:16
verses.text: He is therefore most wretched who has never felt pain, because he is without that which is good; whereas we used to regard him as most happy, because he was without evil.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:17
verses.text: He was not far distant from this folly, who said that the entire absence of pain was the chief good.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:18
verses.text: For, besides the fact that every animal avoids pain, who can bestow upon himself that good, towards the obtaining of which we can do no more than wish? But the chief good cannot make any one happy, unless it shall be always in his power; and it is not virtue, nor learning, nor labour, which affords this to man, but nature herself bestows it upon all living creatures.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:19
verses.text: They who joined pleasure with virtuous principle, wished to avoid this common blending together of all, but they made a contradictory kind of good; since he who is abandoned to pleasure must of necessity be destitute of virtuous principle, and he who aims at principle must be destitute of pleasure.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:20
verses.text: The chief good of the Peripatetics may possibly appear excessive, various, and—excepting those goods which belong to the mind, and what they are is a great subject of dispute—common to man with the beasts.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:21
verses.text: For goods belonging to the body—that is, safety, freedom from pain, health—are no less necessary for dumb creatures than for man; and I know not if they are not more necessary for them, because man can be relieved by remedies and services, the dumb animals cannot.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:22
verses.text: The same is true of those which they call the goods of fortune; for as man has need of resources for the support of life, so have they need of prey and pasture.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:23
verses.text: Thus, by introducing a good which is not within the power of man, they made man altogether subject to the power of another.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:24
verses.text: Let us also hear Zeno, for he at times dreams of virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:25
verses.text: The chief good, he says, is to live in accordance with nature.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:26
verses.text: Therefore we must live after the manner of the brutes.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:27
verses.text: For in these are found all the things which ought to be absent from man: they are eager for pleasures, they fear, they deceive, they lie in wait, they kill; and that which is especially to the point, they have no knowledge of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:28
verses.text: Why, therefore, does he teach me to live according to nature, which is of itself prone to a worse course, and under the influence of some more soothing blandishments plunges headlong into vices? Or if he says that the nature of brutes is different from the nature of man, because man is born to virtue, he says something to the purpose; but, however, it will not be a definition of the chief good, because there is no animal which does not live in accordance with its nature.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:29
verses.text: He who made knowledge the chief good, gave something peculiar to man; but men desire knowledge for the sake of something else, and not for its own sake.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:30
verses.text: For who is contented with knowing, without seeking some advantage from his knowledge? The arts are learned for the purpose of being put into exercise; but they are exercised either for the support of life, or pleasure, or for glory.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:31
verses.text: That, therefore, is not the chief good which is not sought for on its own account.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:32
verses.text: What difference, therefore, does it make, whether we consider knowledge to be the chief good, or those very things which knowledge produces from itself, that is, means of subsistence, glory, pleasure? And these things are not peculiar to man, and therefore they are not the chief goods; for the desire of pleasure and of food does not exist in man alone, but also in the brutes.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:33
verses.text: How is it with regard to the desire of glory? Is it not discovered in horses, since they exult in victory, and are grieved when vanquished? "So great is their love of praises, so great is their eagerness for victory".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:34
verses.text: Nor without reason does that most excellent poet say that we must try "what grief they feel when overcome, and how they rejoice in victory".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:35
verses.text: But if those things which knowledge produces are common to man with other animals, it follows that knowledge is not the chief good.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:36
verses.text: Moreover, it is no slight fault of this definition that bare knowledge is set forth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:37
verses.text: For all will begin to appear happy who shall have the knowledge of any art, even those who shall know mischievous subjects; so that he who shall have learned to mix poisons, is as happy as he who has learned to apply remedies.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:38
verses.text: I ask, therefore, to what subject knowledge is to be referred.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:39
verses.text: If to the causes of natural things, what happiness will be proposed to me, if I shall know the sources of the Nile, or the vain dreams of the natural philosophers respecting the heaven? Why should I mention that on these subjects there is no knowledge, but mere conjecture, which varies according to the abilities of men? It only remains that the knowledge of good and evil things is the chief good.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:40
verses.text: Why, then, did he call knowledge the chief good more than wisdom, when both words have the same signification and meaning? But no one has yet said that the chief good is wisdom, though this might more properly have been said.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:41
verses.text: For knowledge is insufficient for the undertaking of that which is good and avoiding that which is evil, unless virtue also is added.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:42
verses.text: For many of the philosophers, though they discussed the nature of good and evil things, yet from the compulsion of nature lived in a manner different from their discourse, because they were without virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:43
verses.text: But virtue united with knowledge is wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:44
verses.text: It remains that we refute those also who judged virtue itself to be the chief good, and Marcus Tullius was also of this opinion; and in this they were very inconsiderate.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:45
verses.text: For virtue itself is not the chief good, but it is the contriver and mother of the chief good; for this cannot be attained without virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:46
verses.text: Each point is easily understood.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:47
verses.text: For I ask whether they imagine that it is easy to arrive at that distinguished good, or that it is reached only with difficulty and labour? Let them apply their ingenuity, and defend error.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:48
verses.text: If it is easily attained to, and without labour, it cannot be the chief good.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:49
verses.text: For why should we torment ourselves, why wear ourselves out with striving day and night, seeing that the object of our pursuit is so close at hand, that any one who wishes may grasp it without any effort of the mind? But if we do not attain even to a common and moderate good except by labour, since good things are by their nature arduous and difficult, whereas evil things have a downward tendency, it follows that the greatest labour is necessary for the attainment of the greatest good.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:50
verses.text: And if this is most true, then there is need of another virtue, that we may arrive at that virtue which is called the chief good; but this is incongruous and absurd, that virtue should arrive at itself by means of itself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:51
verses.text: If no good can be reached unless by labour, it is evident that it is virtue by which it is reached, since the force and office of virtue consist in the undertaking and carrying through of labours.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:52
verses.text: Therefore the chief good cannot be that by which it is necessary to arrive at another.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:53
verses.text: But they, since they were ignorant of the effects and tendency of virtue, and could discover nothing more honourable, stopped at the very name of virtue, and said that it ought to be sought, though no advantage was proposed from it; and thus they fixed for themselves a good which itself stood in need of a good.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:54
verses.text: From these Aristotle was not far removed, who thought that virtue together with honour was the chief good; as though it were possible for any virtue to exist unless it were honourable, and as though it would not cease to be virtue if it had any measure of disgrace.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:55
verses.text: But he saw that it might happen that a bad opinion is entertained respecting virtue by a depraved judgment, and therefore he thought that deference should be paid to what in the estimation of men constitutes a departure from what is right and good, because it is not in our power that virtue should be honoured simply for its own deserts.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:56
verses.text: For what is honourable character, except perpetual honour, conferred on any one by the favourable report of the people? What, then, will happen, if through the error and perverseness of men a bad reputation should ensue? Shall we cast aside virtue because it is judged to be base and disgraceful by the foolish? And since it is capable of being oppressed and harassed, in order that it may be of itself a peculiar and lasting good, it ought to stand in need of no outward assistance, so as not to depend by itself upon its own strength, and to remain stedfast.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 8:57
verses.text: And thus no good is to be hoped by it from man, nor is any evil to be refused.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:2
verses.text: IX.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:3
verses.text: —Of the Chief Good, and the Worship of the True God, and a Refutation of Anaxagoras.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:4
verses.text: I now come to the chief good of true wisdom, the nature of which is to be determined in this manner: first, it must be the property of man alone, and not belong to any other animal; secondly, it must belong to the soul only, and not be shared with the body; lastly, it cannot fall to the lot of any one without knowledge and virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:5
verses.text: Now this limitation excludes and does away with all the opinions of those whom I have mentioned; for their sayings contain nothing of this kind.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:6
verses.text: I will now say what this is, that I may show, as I designed, that all philosophers were blind and foolish, who could neither see, nor understand, nor surmise at any time what was fixed as the chief good for man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:7
verses.text: Anaxagoras, when asked for what purpose he was born, replied that he might look upon the heaven and the sun.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:8
verses.text: This expression is admired by all, and judged worthy of a philosopher.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:9
verses.text: But I think that he, being unprepared with an answer, uttered this at random, that he might not be silent.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:10
verses.text: But if he had been wise, he ought to have considered and reflected with himself; for if any one is ignorant of his own condition, he cannot even he a man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:11
verses.text: But let us imagine that the saying was not uttered on the spur of the moment.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:12
verses.text: Let us see how many and what great errors he committed in three words.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:13
verses.text: First, he erred in placing the whole duty of man in the eyes alone, referring nothing to the mind, but everything to the body.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:14
verses.text: But if he had been blind, would he lose the duty of a man, which cannot happen without the ruin of the soul? What of the other parts of the body? Will they be destitute, each of its own duty? Why should I say that more depends upon the ears than upon the eye, since learning and wisdom can be gained by the ears only, but not by the eyes only? Were you born for the sake of seeing the heaven and the sun? Who introduced you to this sight? or what does your vision contribute to the heaven and the nature of things? Doubtless that you may praise this immense and wonderful work.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:15
verses.text: Therefore confess that God is the Creator of all things, who introduced you into this world, as a witness and praiser of His great work.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:16
verses.text: You believe that it is a great thing to behold the heaven and the sun: why, therefore, do you not give thanks to Him who is the author of this benefit? why do you not measure with your mind the excellence, the providence, and the power of Him whose works you admire? For it must be, that He who created objects worthy of admiration, is Himself much more to be admired.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:17
verses.text: If any one had invited you to dinner, and you had been well entertained, should you appear in your senses, if you esteemed the mere pleasure more highly than the author of the pleasure? So entirely do philosophers refer all things to the body, and nothing at all to the mind, nor do they see beyond that which fails under their eyes.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:18
verses.text: But all the offices of the body being put aside, the business of man is to be placed in the mind alone.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:19
verses.text: Therefore we are not born for this purpose, that we may see those things which are created, but that we may contemplate, that is, behold with our mind, the Creator of all things Himself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:20
verses.text: Wherefore, if any one should ask a man who is truly wise for what purpose he was born, he will answer without fear or hesitation, that he was born for the purpose of worshipping God, who brought us into being for his cause, that we may serve Him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:21
verses.text: But to serve God is nothing else than to maintain and preserve justice by good works.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:22
verses.text: But he, as a man ignorant of divine things, reduced a matter of the greatest magnitude to the least, by selecting two things only, which he said were to be beheld by him.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:23
verses.text: But if he had said that he was born to behold the world, although he would comprise all things in this, and would use an expression of greater sound, yet he would not have completed the duty of man; for as much as the soul excels the body, so much does God excel the world, for God made and governs the world.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:24
verses.text: Therefore it is not the world which is to be contemplated by the eye, for each is a body; but it is God who is to be contemplated by the soul: for God, being Himself immortal, willed that the soul also should be everlasting.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:25
verses.text: But the contemplation of God is the reverence and worship of the common Parent of mankind.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:26
verses.text: And if the philosophers were destitute of this, and in their ignorance of divine things prostrated themselves to the earth, we must suppose that Anaxagoras neither beheld the heaven nor the sun, though he said that he was born that he might behold them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:27
verses.text: The object proposed to man is therefore plain and easy, if he is wise; and to it especially belongs humanity.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 9:28
verses.text: For what is humanity itself, but justice? what is justice, but piety? And piety is nothing else than the recognition of God as a parent.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:2
verses.text: X.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:3
verses.text: —It is the Peculiar Property of Man to Know and Worship God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:4
verses.text: Therefore the chief good of man is in religion only; for the other things, even those which are supposed to be peculiar to man, are found in the other animals also.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:5
verses.text: For when they discern and distinguish their own voices by peculiar marks among themselves, they seem to converse: they also appear to have a kind of smile, when with soothed ears, and contracted mouth, and with eyes relaxed to sportiveness, they fawn upon man, or upon their own mates and young.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:6
verses.text: Do they not give a greeting which bears some resemblance to mutual love and indulgence? Again, those creatures which look forward to the future and lay up for themselves food, plainly have foresight.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:7
verses.text: Indications of reason are also found in many of them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:8
verses.text: For since they desire things useful to themselves, guard against evils, avoid dangers, prepare for themselves lurking-places standing open in different places with various outlets, assuredly they have some understanding.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:9
verses.text: Can any one deny that they are possessed of reason, since they often deceive man himself? For those which have the office of producing honey, when they inhabit the place assigned to them, fortify a camp, construct dwellings with unspeakable skill, and obey their king; I know not if there is not in them perfect prudence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:10
verses.text: It is therefore uncertain whether those things which are given to man are common to him with other living creatures: they are certainly without religion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:11
verses.text: I indeed thus judge, that reason is given to all animals, but to the dumb creatures only for the protection of life, to man also for its prolongation.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:12
verses.text: And because reason itself is perfect in man, it is named wisdom, which renders man distinguished in this respect, that to him alone it is given to comprehend divine things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:13
verses.text: And concerning this the opinion of Cicero is true: "Of so many kinds of animals," he says, "there is none except man which has any knowledge of God; and among men themselves, there is no nation either so uncivilized or so savage, which, even if it is ignorant of due conceptions of the Deity, does not know that some conception of Him ought to be entertained".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:14
verses.text: From which it is effected, that he acknowledges God, who, as it were, calls to mind the source from which he is sprung.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:15
verses.text: Those philosophers, therefore, who wish to free the mind from all fear, take away even religion, and thus deprive man of his peculiar and surpassing good, which is distinct from living uprightly, and from everything connected with man, because God, who made all living creatures subject to man, also made man subject to Himself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:16
verses.text: What reason is there why they should also maintain that the mind is to be turned in the same direction to which the countenance is raised? For if we must look to the heaven, it is undoubtedly for no other reason than on account of religion; if religion is taken away, we have nothing to do with the heaven.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:17
verses.text: Therefore we must either look in that direction or bend down to the earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:18
verses.text: We are not able to bend down to the earth, even if we should wish, since our posture is upright.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:19
verses.text: We must therefore look up to the heaven, to which the nature of the body calls us.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:20
verses.text: And if it is admitted that this must be done, it must either be done with this view, that we may devote ourselves to religion, or that we may know the nature of the heavenly objects.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:21
verses.text: But we cannot by any means know the nature of the heavenly objects, because nothing of that kind can be found out by reflection, as I have before shown.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:22
verses.text: We must therefore devote ourselves to religion, and he who does not undertake this prostrates himself to the ground, and, imitating the life of the brutes, abdicates the office of man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 10:23
verses.text: Therefore the ignorant are more wise; for although they err in choosing religion, yet they remember their own nature and condition.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:2
verses.text: XI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:3
verses.text: —Of Religion, Wisdom, and the Chief Good.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:4
verses.text: It is agreed upon, therefore, by the general consent of all mankind, that religion ought to be undertaken; but we have to explain what errors are committed on this subject.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:5
verses.text: God willed this to be the nature of man, that he should be desirous and eager for two things, religion and wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:6
verses.text: But men are mistaken in this, that they either undertake religion and pay no attention to wisdom, or they devote themselves to wisdom alone, and pay no attention to religion, though the one cannot be true without the other.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:7
verses.text: The consequence is, that they fall into a multiplicity of religions, but false ones, because they have left wisdom, which could have taught them that there cannot be many gods; or they devote themselves to wisdom, but a false wisdom, because they have paid no attention to the religion of the Supreme God, who might have instructed them to the knowledge of the truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:8
verses.text: Thus men who undertake either of these courses follow a devious path, and one full of the greatest errors, inasmuch as the duty of man, and all truth, are included in these two things which are inseparably connected.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:9
verses.text: I wonder, therefore, that there was none at all of the philosophers who discovered the abode and dwelling-place of the chief good.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:10
verses.text: For they might have sought it in this manner.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:11
verses.text: Whatever the greatest good is, it must be an object proposed to all men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:12
verses.text: There is pleasure, which is desired by all; but this is common also to man with the beasts, and has not the force of the honourable, and brings a feeling of satiety, and when it is in excess is injurious, and it is lessened by advance of age, and does not fall to the lot of many: for they who are without resources, who constitute the greater part of men, must also be without pleasure.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:13
verses.text: Therefore pleasure is not the chief good; but it is not even a good.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:14
verses.text: What shall we say of riches? This is much more true of them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:15
verses.text: For they fall to the lot of fewer men, and that generally by chance; and they often fall to the indolent, and sometimes by guilt, and they are desired by those who already possess them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:16
verses.text: What shall we say of sovereignty itself? That does not constitute the chief good: for all cannot reign, but it is necessary that all should be capable of attaining the chief good.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:17
verses.text: Let us therefore seek something which is held forth to all.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:18
verses.text: Is it virtue? It cannot be denied that virtue is a good, and undoubtedly a good for all men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:19
verses.text: But if it cannot be happy because its power and nature consist in the endurance of evil, it assuredly is not the chief good.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:20
verses.text: Let us seek something else.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:21
verses.text: But nothing can be found more beautiful than virtue, nothing more worthy of a wise man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:22
verses.text: For if vices are to be avoided on account of their deformity, virtue is therefore to be desired on account of its beauty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:23
verses.text: What then? Can it be that that which is admitted to be good and honourable should be requited with no reward, and be so unproductive as to procure no advantage from itself? That great labour and difficulty and struggling against evils with which this life is filled, must of necessity produce some great good.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:24
verses.text: But what shall we say that it is? Pleasure? But nothing that is base can arise from that which is honourable.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:25
verses.text: Shall we say that it is riches? or commands? But these things are frail and uncertain.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:26
verses.text: Is it glory? or honour? or a lasting name? But all these things are not contained in virtue itself, but depend upon the opinion and judgment of others.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:27
verses.text: For virtue is often hated and visited with evil.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:28
verses.text: But the good which arises from it ought to be so closely united with it as to be incapable of being separated or disunited from it; and it cannot appear to be the chief good in any other way than if it belongs peculiarly to virtue, and is such that nothing can be added to it or taken from it.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:29
verses.text: Why should I say that the duties of virtue consist in the despising of all these things? For not to long for, or desire, or love pleasures, riches, dominions, and honours, and all those things which are esteemed as goods, as others do overpowered by desire, that assuredly is virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:30
verses.text: Therefore it effects something else more sublime and excellent; nor does anything struggle against these present goods but that which longs for greater and truer things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 11:31
verses.text: Let us not despair of being able to find it, if we turn our thoughts in all directions; for no slight or trifling rewards are sought.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:2
verses.text: XII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:3
verses.text: —Of the Twofold Conflict of Body and Soul; And of Desiring Virtue on Account of Eternal Life.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:4
verses.text: But our inquiry is as to the object for which we are born: and thus we are able to trace out what is the effect of virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:5
verses.text: There are two parts of which man is made up, soul and body.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:6
verses.text: There are many things peculiar to the soul, many peculiar to the body, many common to both, as is virtue itself; and as often as this is referred to the body, it is called fortitude for the sake of distinction.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:7
verses.text: Since, therefore, fortitude is connected with each, a contest is proposed to each, and victory held forth to each from the contest: the body, because it is solid, and capable of being grasped, must contend with objects which are solid and can be grasped; but the soul, on the other hand, because it is slight and subtle, and invisible, contends with those enemies who cannot be seen and touched.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:8
verses.text: But what are the enemies of the soul, but lusts, vices, and sins? And if virtue shall have overcome and put to flight these, the soul will be pure and free from stain.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:9
verses.text: Whence, then, are we able to collect what are the effects of fortitude of soul? Doubtless from that which is closely connected with it, and resembles it, that is, from fortitude of the body; for when this has come to any encounter and contest, what else does it seek from victory but life? For whether you contend with a man or beast, the contest is for safety.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:10
verses.text: Therefore, as the body obtains by victory its preservation from destruction, so the soul obtains a continuation of its existence; and as the body, when overcome by its enemies, suffers death, so the soul, when overpowered by vices, must die.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:11
verses.text: What difference, therefore, will there be between the contest carried on by the soul and that carried on by the body, except that the body seeks for temporal, but the soul eternal life? If, therefore, virtue is not happy by itself, since its whole force consists, as I have said, in the enduring of evils; if it neglects all things which are desired as goods; if in its highest condition it is exposed to death, inasmuch as it often refuses life, which is desired by others, and bravely undergoes death, which others fear; if it must necessarily produce some great good from itself, because labours, endured and overcome even until death, cannot fail of obtaining a reward; if no reward, such as it deserves, is found on earth, inasmuch as it despises all things which are frail and transitory, what else remains but that it may effect some heavenly reward, since it treats with contempt all earthly things, and may aim at higher things, since it despises things that are humble? And this reward can be nothing else but immortality.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:12
verses.text: With good reason, therefore, did Euclid, no obscure philosopher, who was the founder of the system of the Megareans, differing from the others, say that that was the chief good which was unvarying and always the same.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:13
verses.text: He certainly understood what is the nature of the chief good, although he did not explain in what it consisted; but it consists of immortality, nor anything else at all, inasmuch as it alone is incapable of diminution, or increase, or change.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:14
verses.text: Seneca also unconsciously happened to confess that there is no other reward of virtue than immortality.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:15
verses.text: For in praising virtue in the treatise which he wrote on the subject of premature death, he says: "Virtue is the only thing which can confer upon us immortality, and make us equal to the gods".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:16
verses.text: But the Stoics also, whom he followed, say that no one can be made happy without virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:17
verses.text: Therefore, the reward of virtue is a happy life, if virtue, as it is rightly said, makes a happy life.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:18
verses.text: Virtue, therefore, is not, as they say, to be sought on its own account, but on account of a happy life, which necessarily follows virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:19
verses.text: And this argument might have taught them in what the chief good consisted.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:20
verses.text: But this present and corporeal life cannot be happy, because it is subjected to evils through the body.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:21
verses.text: Epicurus calls God happy and incorruptible, because He is everlasting.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 12:22
verses.text: For a state of happiness ought to be perfect, so that there may be nothing which can harass, or lessen, or change it.
