verses.text: For if even by chance they have seen the truth—a thing which often happens—they so act that it is refuted by others as false.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:14
verses.text: For no one descends from heaven to pass sentence on the opinions of individuals; wherefore no one can doubt that those who seek after these things are foolish, senseless, and insane.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:15
verses.text: Socrates therefore had something of human wisdom, who, when he understood that these things could not possibly be ascertained, removed himself from questions of this kind; but I fear that he so acted in this alone.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:16
verses.text: For many of his actions are not only undeserving of praise, but also most deserving of censure, in which things he most resembled those of his own class.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:17
verses.text: Out of these I will select one which may be judged of by all.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:18
verses.text: Socrates used this well-known proverb: "That which is above us is nothing to us".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:19
verses.text: Let us therefore fall down upon the earth, and use as feet those hands which have been given us for the production of excellent works.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:20
verses.text: The heaven is nothing to us, to the contemplation of which we have been raised; in fine, the light itself can have no reference to us; undoubtedly the cause of our sustenance is from heaven.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:21
verses.text: But if he perceived this, that we ought not to discuss the nature of heavenly things, he was unable even to comprehend the nature of those things which he had beneath his feet.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:22
verses.text: What then? did he err in his words? It is not probable; but he undoubtedly meant that which he said, that we are not to devote ourselves to religion; but if he were openly to say this, no one would suffer it.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:23
verses.text: For who cannot perceive that this world, completed with such wonderful method, is governed by some providence, since there is nothing which can exist without some one to direct it? Thus, a house deserted by its inhabitant fails to decay; a ship without a pilot goes to the bottom; and a body abandoned by the soul wastes away.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:24
verses.text: Much less can we suppose that so great a fabric could either have been constructed without an Artificer, or have existed so long without a Ruler.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:25
verses.text: But if he wished to overthrow those public superstitions, I do not disapprove of this; yea, I shall rather praise it, if he shall have found anything better to take their place.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:26
verses.text: But the same man swore by a dog and a goose.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:27
verses.text: Oh buffoon (as Zeno the Epicurean says), senseless, abandoned, desperate man, if he wished to scoff at religion; madman, if he did this seriously, so as to esteem a most base animal as God! For who can dare to find fault with the superstitions of the Egyptians, when Socrates confirmed them at Athens by his authority? But was it not a mark of consummate vanity, that before his death he asked his friends to sacrifice for him a cock which he had vowed to aesculapius? He evidently feared lest he should be put upon his trial before Rhadamanthus, the judge, by aesculapius on account of the vow.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:28
verses.text: I should consider him most mad if he had died under the influence of disease.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:29
verses.text: But since he did this in his sound mind, he who thinks that he was wise is himself of unsound mind.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 20:30
verses.text: Behold one in whose times the wise man congratulates himself as having been born!.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:2
verses.text: XXI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:3
verses.text: —Of the System of Plato, Which Would Lead to the Overthrow of States.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:4
verses.text: Let us, however, see what it was that he learned from Socrates, who, having entirely rejected natural philosophy, betook himself to inquiries about virtue and duty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:5
verses.text: And thus I do not doubt that he instructed his hearers in the precepts of justice.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:6
verses.text: Therefore, under the teaching of Socrates, it did not escape the notice of Plato, that the force of justice consists in equality, since all are born in an equal condition.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:7
verses.text: Therefore (he says) they must have nothing private or their own; but that they may be equal, as the method of justice requires, they must possess all things in common.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:8
verses.text: This is capable of being endured, as long as it appears to be spoken of money.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:9
verses.text: But how impossible and how unjust this is, I could show by many things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:10
verses.text: Let us, however, admit its possibility.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:11
verses.text: For grant that all are wise, and despise money.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:12
verses.text: To what, then, did that community lead him? Marriages also, be says, ought to be in common; so that many men may flock together like dogs to the same woman, and he who shall be superior in strength may succeed in obtaining her; or if they are patient as philosophers, they may await their turns, as in a brothel.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:13
verses.text: Oh the wonderful equality of Plato! Where, then, is the virtue of chastity? where conjugal fidelity? And if you take away these, all justice is taken away.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:14
verses.text: But he also says that states would be prosperous, if either philosophers were their kings, or their kings were philosophers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:15
verses.text: But if you were to give the sovereignty to this man of such justice and equity, who had deprived some of their own property, and given to some the property of others, he would prostitute the modesty of women; a thing which was never done, I do not say by a king, but not even by a tyrant.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:16
verses.text: But what motive did he advance for this most degrading advice? The state will be in harmony, and bound together with the bonds of mutual love, if all shall be the husbands, and fathers, and wives, and children of all.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:17
verses.text: What a confusion of the human race is this? How is it possible for affection to be preserved where there is nothing certain to be loved? What man will love a woman, or what woman a man, unless they shall always have lived together,—unless devotedness of mind, and faith mutually preserved, shall have made their love indivisible? But this virtue has no place in that promiscuous pleasure.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:18
verses.text: Moreover, if all are the children of all, who will be able to love children as his own, when he is either ignorant or in doubt whether they are his own? Who will bestow honour upon any one as a father, when he does not know from whom he was born? From which it comes to pass, that he not only esteems a stranger as a father, but also a father as a stranger.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:19
verses.text: Why should I say that it is possible for a wife to be common, but impossible for a son, who cannot be conceived except from one? The community, therefore, is lost to him alone, nature herself crying out against it.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:20
verses.text: It remains that it is only for the sake of concord that he would have a community of wives.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:21
verses.text: But there is no more vehement cause of discords, than the desire of one woman by many men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 21:22
verses.text: And in this Plato might have been admonished, if not by reason, yet certainly by example, both of the dumb animals, which fight most vehemently on this account, and of men, who have always carried on most severe wars with one another on account of this matter.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:2
verses.text: XXII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:3
verses.text: —Of the Precepts of Plato, and Censures of the Same.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:4
verses.text: It remains that the community of which we have spoken admits of nothing else but adulteries and lusts, for the utter extinction of which virtue is especially necessary.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:5
verses.text: Therefore he did not find the concord which he sought, because he did not see whence it arises.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:6
verses.text: For justice has no weight in outward circumstances, not even in the body, but it is altogether employed on the mind of man.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:7
verses.text: He, therefore, who wishes to place men on an equality, ought not to take away marriage and wealth, but arrogance, pride, and haughtiness, that those who are powerful and lifted up on high may know that they are on a level even with the most needy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:8
verses.text: For insolence and injustice being taken from the rich, it will make no difference whether some are rich and others poor, since they will be equal in spirit, and nothing but reverence towards God can produce this result.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:9
verses.text: He thought, therefore, that he had found justice, whereas he had altogether removed it, because it ought not to be a community of perishable things, but of minds.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:10
verses.text: For if justice is the mother of all virtues, when they are severally taken away, it is also itself overthrown.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:11
verses.text: But Plato took away above all things frugality, which has no existence when there is no property of one's own which can be possessed; he took away abstinence, since there will be nothing belonging to another from which one can abstain; he took away temperance and chastity, which are the greatest virtues in each sex; he took away self-respect, shame, and modesty, if those things which are accustomed to be judged base and disgraceful begin to be accounted honourable and lawful.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:12
verses.text: Thus, while he wishes to confer virtue upon all, he takes it away from all.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:13
verses.text: For the ownership of property contains the material both of vices and of virtues, but a community of goods contains nothing else than the licentiousness of vices.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:14
verses.text: For men who have many mistresses can be called nothing else than luxurious and prodigal.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:15
verses.text: And likewise women who are in the possession of many men, must of necessity be not adulteresses, because they have no fixed marriage, but prostitutes and harlots.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:16
verses.text: Therefore he reduced human life, I do not say to the likeness of dumb animals, but of the herds and brutes.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:17
verses.text: For almost all the birds contract marriages, and are united in pairs, and defend their nests, as though their marriage-beds, with harmonious mind, and cherish their own young, because they are well known to them; and if you put others in their way, they repel them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:18
verses.text: But this wise man, contrary to the custom of men, and contrary to nature, chose more foolish objects of imitation; and since he saw that the duties of males and females were not separated in the case of other animals, he thought that women also ought to engage in warfare, and take a share in the public counsels, and undertake magistracies, and assume commands.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:19
verses.text: And therefore he assigned to them horses and arms: it follows that he should have assigned to men wool and the loom, and the carrying of infants.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 22:20
verses.text: Nor did he see the impossibility of what he said, from the fact that no nation has existed in the world so foolish or so vain as to live in this manner.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:2
verses.text: XXIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:3
verses.text: —Of the Errors of Certain Philosophers, and of the Sun and Moon.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:4
verses.text: Since, therefore, the leading men among the philosophers are themselves discovered to be of such emptiness, what shall we think of those lesser ones, who are accustomed never to appear to themselves so wise, as when they boast of their contempt of money? Brave spirit! But I wait to see their conduct, and what are the results of that contempt.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:5
verses.text: They avoid as an evil, and abandon the property handed down to them from their parents.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:6
verses.text: And lest they should suffer shipwreck in a storm, they plunge headlong of their own accord in a calm, being resolute not by virtue, but by perverse fear; as those who, through fear of being slain by the enemy, slay themselves, that by death they may avoid death.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:7
verses.text: So these men, without honour and without influence, throw away the means by which they might have acquired the glory of liberality.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:8
verses.text: Democritus is praised because he abandoned his fields, and suffered them to become public pastures.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:9
verses.text: I should approve of it, if he had given them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:10
verses.text: But nothing is done wisely which is useless and evil if it is done by all.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:11
verses.text: But this negligence is tolerable.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:12
verses.text: What shall I say of him who changed his possessions into money, which he threw into the sea? I doubt whether he was in his senses, or deranged.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:13
verses.text: Away, he says, ye evil desires, into the deep.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:14
verses.text: I will cast you away, lest I myself should be cast away by you.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:15
verses.text: If you have so great a contempt for money, employ it in acts of kindness and humanity, bestow it upon the poor; this, which you are about to throw away, may be a succour to many, so that they may not die through famine, or thirst, or nakedness.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:16
verses.text: Imitate at least the madness and fury of Tuditanus; scatter abroad your property to be seized by the people.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:17
verses.text: You have it in your power both to escape the possession of money, and yet to lay it out to advantage; for whatever has been profitable to many is securely laid out.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:18
verses.text: But who approves of the equality of faults as laid down by Zeno? But let us omit that which is always received with derision by all.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:19
verses.text: This is sufficient to prove the error of this madman, that he places pity among vices and diseases.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:20
verses.text: He deprives us of an affection, which involves almost the whole course of human life.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:21
verses.text: For since the nature of man is more feeble than that of the other animals, which divine providence has armed with natural means of protection, either to endure the severity of the seasons or to ward off attacks from their bodies, because none of these things has been given to man, he has received in the place of all these things the affection of pity, which is truly called humanity, by which we might mutually protect each other.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:22
verses.text: For if a man were rendered savage by the sight of another man, which we see happen in the case of those animals which are of a solitary nature, there would be no society among men, no care or system in the building of cities; and thus life would not even be safe, since the weakness of men would both be exposed to the attacks of the other animals, and they would rage among themselves after the manner of wild beasts.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:23
verses.text: Nor is his madness less in other things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:24
verses.text: For what can be said respecting him who asserted that snow was black? How naturally it followed, that he should also assert that pitch was white! This is he who said that he was born for this purpose, that he might behold the heaven and the sun, who beheld nothing on the earth when the sun was shining.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:25
verses.text: Xenophanes most foolishly believed mathematicians who said that the orb of the moon was eighteen times larger than the earth; and, as was consistent with this folly, he said that within the concave surface of the moon there was another earth, and that there another race of men live in a similar manner to that in which we live on this earth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:26
verses.text: Therefore these lunatics have another moon, to hold forth to them a light by night, as this does to us.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:27
verses.text: And perhaps this globe of ours may be a moon to another earth below this.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:28
verses.text: Seneca says that there was one among the Stoics who used to deliberate whether he should assign to the sun also its own inhabitants; he acted foolishly in doubting.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 23:29
verses.text: For what injury would he have inflicted if he had assigned them? But I believe the heat deterred him, so as not to imperil so great a multitude; lest, if they should perish through excessive heat, so great a calamity should be said to have happened by his fault.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:2
verses.text: XXIV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:3
verses.text: —Of the Antipodes, the Heaven, and the Stars.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:4
verses.text: How is it with those who imagine that there are antipodes opposite to our footsteps? Do they say anything to the purpose? Or is there any one so senseless as to believe that there are men whose footsteps are higher than their heads? or that the things which with us are in a recumbent position, with them hang in an inverted direction? that the crops and trees grow downwards? that the rains, and snow, and hail fall upwards to the earth? And does any one wonder that hanging gardens are mentioned among the seven wonders of the world, when philosophers make hanging fields, and seas, and cities, and mountains? The origin of this error must also be set forth by us.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:5
verses.text: For they are always deceived in the same manner.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:6
verses.text: For when they have assumed anything false in the commencement of their investigations, led by the resemblance of the truth, they necessarily fall into those things which are its consequences.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:7
verses.text: Thus they fall into many ridiculous things; because those things which are in agreement with false things, must themselves be false.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:8
verses.text: But since they placed confidence in the first, they do not consider the character of those things which follow, but defend them in every way; whereas they ought to judge from those which follow, whether the first are true or false.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:9
verses.text: What course of argument, therefore, led them to the idea of the antipodes? They saw the courses of the stars travelling towards the west; they saw that the sun and the moon always set towards the same quarter, and rise from the same.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:10
verses.text: But since they did not perceive what contrivance regulated their courses, nor how they returned from the west to the east, but supposed that the heaven itself sloped downwards in every direction, which appearance it must present on account of its immense breadth, they thought that the world is round like a ball, and they fancied that the heaven revolves in accordance with the motion of the heavenly bodies; and thus that the stars and sun, when they have set, by the very rapidity of the motion of the world are borne back to the east.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:11
verses.text: Therefore they both constructed brazen orbs, as though after the figure of the world, and engraved upon them certain monstrous images, which they said were constellations.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:12
verses.text: It followed, therefore, from this rotundity of the heaven, that the earth was enclosed in the midst of its curved surface.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:13
verses.text: But if this were so, the earth also itself must be like a globe; for that could not possibly be anything but round, which was held enclosed by that which was round.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:14
verses.text: But if the earth also were round, it must necessarily happen that it should present the same appearance to all parts of the heaven; that is, that it should raise aloft mountains, extend plains, and have level seas.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:15
verses.text: And if this were so, that last consequence also followed, that there would be no part of the earth uninhabited by men and the other animals.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:16
verses.text: Thus the rotundity of the earth leads, in addition, to the invention of those suspended antipodes.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:17
verses.text: But if you inquire from those who defend these marvellous fictions, why all things do not fall into that lower part of the heaven, they reply that such is the nature of things, that heavy bodies are borne to the middle, and that they are all joined together towards the middle, as we see spokes in a wheel; but that the bodies which are light, as mist, smoke, and fire, are borne away from the middle, so as to seek the heaven.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:18
verses.text: I am at a loss what to say respecting those who, when they have once erred, consistently persevere in their folly, and defend one vain thing by another; but that I sometimes imagine that they either discuss philosophy for the sake of a jest, or purposely and knowingly undertake to defend falsehoods, as if to exercise or display their talents on false subjects.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:19
verses.text: But I should be able to prove by many arguments that it is impossible for the heaven to be lower than the earth, were is not that this book must now be concluded, and that some things still remain, which are more necessary for the present work.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 24:20
verses.text: And since it is not the work of a single book to run over the errors of each individually, let it be sufficient to have enumerated a few, from which the nature of the others may be understood.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:2
verses.text: XXV.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:3
verses.text: —Of Learning Philosophy, and What Great Qualifications are Necessary for Its Pursuit.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:4
verses.text: We must now speak a few things concerning philosophy in general, that having strengthened our cause we may conclude.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:5
verses.text: That greatest imitator of Plato among our writers thought that philosophy was not for the multitude, because none but learned men could attain to it.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:6
verses.text: "Philosophy," says Cicero, "is contented with a few judges, of its own accord designedly avoiding the multitude".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:7
verses.text: It is not therefore wisdom, if it avoids the concourse of men; since, if wisdom is given to man, it is given to all without any distinction, so that there is no one at all who cannot acquire it.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:8
verses.text: But they so embrace virtue, which is given to the human race, that they alone of all appear to wish to enjoy that which is a public good; being as envious as if they should wish to bind or tear out the eyes of others that they may not see the sun.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:9
verses.text: For what else is it to deny wisdom to men, than to take away from their minds the true and divine light? But if the nature of man is capable of wisdom, it was befitting that both workmen, and country people, and women, and all, in short, who bear the human form, should be taught to be wise; and that the people should be brought together from every language, and condition, and sex, and age.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:10
verses.text: Therefore it is a very strong argument that philosophy neither tends to wisdom, nor is of itself wisdom, that its mystery is only made known by the beard and cloak of the philosophers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:11
verses.text: The Stoics, moreover, perceived this, who said that philosophy was to be studied both by slaves and women; Epicurus also, who invites those who are altogether unacquainted with letters to philosophy; and Plato also, who wished to compose a state of wise men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:12
verses.text: They attempted, indeed, to do that which truth required; but they were unable to proceed beyond words.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:13
verses.text: First, because instruction in many arts is necessary for an application to philosophy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:14
verses.text: Common learning must be acquired on account of practice in reading, because in so great a variety of subjects it is impossible that all things should be learned by hearing, or retained in the memory.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:15
verses.text: No little attention also must be given to the grammarians, in order that you may know the right method of speaking.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:16
verses.text: That must occupy many years.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:17
verses.text: Nor must there be ignorance of rhetoric, that you may be able to utter and express the things which you have learned.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:18
verses.text: Geometry also, and music, and astronomy, are necessary, because these arts have some connection with philosophy; and the whole of these subjects cannot be learned by women, who must learn within the years of their maturity the duties which are hereafter about to be of service to them for domestic uses; nor by servants, who must live in service during those years especially in which they are able to learn; nor by the poor, or labourers, or rustics, who have to gain their daily support by labour.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:19
verses.text: And on this account Tully says that philosophy is averse from the multitude.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:20
verses.text: But yet Epicurus will receive the ignorant.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:21
verses.text: How, then, will they understand those things which are said respecting the first principles of things, the perplexities and intricacies of which are scarcely attained to by men of cultivated minds?  Therefore, in subjects which are involved in obscurity, and confused by a variety of intellects, and set off by the studied language of eloquent men, what place is there for the unskilful and ignorant? Lastly, they never taught any women to study philosophy, except Themiste only, within the whole memory of man; nor slaves, except Phaedo only, who is said, when living in oppressive slavery, to have been ransomed and taught by Cebes.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:22
verses.text: They also enumerate Plato and Diogenes: these, however, were not slaves, though they had fallen into servitude, for they had been taken captive.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:23
verses.text: A certain Aniceris is said to have ransomed Plato for eight sesterces.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:24
verses.text: And on this account Seneca severely rebuked the ransomer himself, because he set so small value upon Plato.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:25
verses.text: He was a madman, as it seems to me, who was angry with a man because he did not throw away much money; doubtless he ought to have weighed gold as though to ransom the corpse of Hector, or to have insisted upon the payment of more money than the seller demanded.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 25:26
verses.text: Moreover, they taught none of the barbarians, with the single exception of Anacharsis the Scythian, who never would have dreamed of philosophy had he not previously learned both language and literature.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:2
verses.text: XXVI.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:3
verses.text: —It is Divine Instruction Only Which Bestows Wisdom; And of What Efficacy the Law of God is.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:4
verses.text: That, therefore, which they perceived to be justly required by the demands of nature, but which they were themselves unable to perform, and saw that the philosophers could not effect, is accomplished only by divine instruction; for that only is wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:5
verses.text: Doubtless they were able to persuade any one who do not even persuade themselves of anything; or they will crush the desires, moderate the anger, and restrain the lusts of any one, when they themselves both yield to vices, and acknowledge that they are overpowered by nature.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:6
verses.text: But what influence is exerted on the souls of men by the precepts of God, because of their simplicity and truth, is shown by daily proofs.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:7
verses.text: Give me a man who is passionate, scurrilous, and unrestrained; with a very few words of God,  "I will render him as gentle as a sheep".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:8
verses.text: Give me one who is grasping, covetous, and tenacious; I will presently restore him to you liberal, and freely bestowing his money with full hands.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:9
verses.text: Give me a man who is afraid of pain and death; he shall presently despise crosses, and fires, and the bull of Phalaris.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:10
verses.text: Give me one who is lustful, an adulterer, a glutton; you shall presently see him sober, chaste, and temperate.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:11
verses.text: Give me one who is cruel and bloodthirsty: that fury shall presently be changed into true clemency.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:12
verses.text: Give me a man who is unjust, foolish, an evil-doer; forthwith he shall be just, and wise, and innocent: for by one laver all his wickedness shall be taken away.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:13
verses.text: So great is the power of divine wisdom, that, when infused into the breast of man, by one impulse it once for all expels folly, which is the mother of faults, for the effecting of which there is no need of payment, or books, or nightly studies.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:14
verses.text: These results are accomplished gratuitously, easily, and quickly, if only the ears are open and the breast thirsts for wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:15
verses.text: Let no one fear: we do not sell water, nor offer the sun for a reward.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:16
verses.text: The fountain of God, most abundant and most full, is open to all; and this heavenly light rises for all, as many as have eyes.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:17
verses.text: Did any of the philosophers effect these things, or is he able to effect them if he wishes? For though they spend their lives in the study of philosophy, they are neither able to improve any other person nor themselves (if nature has presented any obstacle).

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:18
verses.text: Therefore their wisdom, doing its utmost, does not eradicate, but hide vices.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 26:19
verses.text: But a few precepts of God so entirely change the whole man, and having put off the old man, render him new, that you would not recognise him as the same.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:2
verses.text: XXVII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:3
verses.text: —How Little the Precepts of Philosophers Contribute to True Wisdom, Which You Will Find in Religion Only.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:4
verses.text: What, then? Do they enjoin nothing similar? Yes, indeed, many things; and they frequently approach the truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:5
verses.text: But those precepts have no weight, because they are human, and are without a greater, that is, that divine authority.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:6
verses.text: No one therefore believes them, because the hearer imagines himself to be a man, just as he is, who enjoins them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:7
verses.text: Moreover, there is no certainty with them, nothing which proceeds from knowledge.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:8
verses.text: But since all things are done by conjecture, and many differing and various things are brought forward, it is the part of a most foolish man to be willing to obey their precepts, since it is doubted whether they are true or false; and therefore no one obeys them, because no one wishes to labour for an uncertainty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:9
verses.text: The Stoics say that it is virtue which can alone produce a happy life.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:10
verses.text: Nothing can be said with greater truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:11
verses.text: But what if he shall be tormented, or afflicted with pain? Will it be possible for any one to be happy in the hands of the executioners? But truly pain inflicted upon the body is the material of virtue; therefore he is not wretched even in tortures.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:12
verses.text: Epicurus speaks much more strongly.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:13
verses.text: The wise man, he says, is always happy; and even when shut up in the bull of Phalaris he will utter this speech: "It is pleasant, and I do not care for it".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:14
verses.text: Who would not laugh at him? Especially, because a man who is devoted to pleasure took upon himself the character of a man of fortitude, and that to an immoderate degree; for it is impossible that any one should esteem tortures of the body as pleasures, since it is sufficient for discharging the office of virtue that one sustains and endures them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:15
verses.text: What do you, Stoics, say? What do you, Epicurus? The wise man is happy even when be is tortured.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:16
verses.text: If it is on account of the glory of his endurance, he will not enjoy it, for perchance he will die under the tortures.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:17
verses.text: If it is on account of the recollection of the deed, either he will not perceive it if souls shall perish, or, if he shall perceive it, he will gain nothing from it.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:18
verses.text: What other advantage is there then in virtue? what happiness of life? Is it that a man may die with equanimity? You present to me the advantage of a single hour, or perhaps moment, for the sake of which it may not be expedient to be worn out by miseries and labours throughout the whole of life.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:19
verses.text: But how much time does death occupy? on the arrival of which it now makes no difference whether you shall have undergone it with equanimity or not.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:20
verses.text: Thus it happens that nothing is sought from virtue but glory.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:21
verses.text: But this is either superfluous and short-lived, or it will not follow from the depraved judgments of men.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:22
verses.text: Therefore there is no fruit from virtue where virtue is subject to death and decay.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:23
verses.text: Therefore they who said these things saw a certain shadow of virtue; they did not see virtue itself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:24
verses.text: For they had their eyes fixed on the earth, nor did they raise their countenances on high that they might behold her  "Who showed herself from the quarters of heaven".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:25
verses.text: This is the reason why no one obeys their precepts; inasmuch as they either train men to vices, if they defend pleasure; or if they uphold virtue, they neither threaten sin with any punishment, except that of disgrace only, nor do they promise any reward to virtue, except that of honour and praise only, since they say that virtue is to be sought for its own sake, and not on account of any other object.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:26
verses.text: The wise man therefore is happy under tortures; but when he suffers torture on account of his faith, on account of justice, or on account of God, that endurance of pain will render him most happy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:27
verses.text: For it is God alone who can honour virtue, the reward of which is immortality alone.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:28
verses.text: And they who do not seek this, nor possess religion, with which eternal life is connected, assuredly do not know the power of virtue, the reward of which they are ignorant; nor look towards heaven, as they themselves imagine that they do, when they inquire into subjects which do not admit of investigation, since there is no other cause for looking towards heaven, unless it be either to undertake religion, or to believe that one's soul is immortal.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:29
verses.text: For if any one understands that God is to be worshipped, or has the hope of immortality set before him, his mind is in heaven; and although he may not behold it with his eyes, yet he does behold it with the eye of his soul.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:30
verses.text: But they who do not take up religion are of the earth, for religion is from heaven; and they who think that the soul perishes together with the body, equally look down towards the earth: for beyond the body, which is earth, they see nothing further, which is immortal.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 27:31
verses.text: It is therefore of no profit that man is so made, that with upright body he looks towards heaven, unless with mind raised aloft he discerns God, and his thoughts are altogether engaged upon the hope of everlasting life.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:2
verses.text: XXVIII.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:3
verses.text: —Of True Religion and of Nature.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:4
verses.text: Whether Fortune is a Goddess, and of Philosophy.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:5
verses.text: Wherefore there is nothing else in life on which our plan and condition can depend but the knowledge of God who created us, and the religious and pious worship of Him; and since the philosophers have wandered from this, it is plain that they were not wise.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:6
verses.text: They sought wisdom, indeed; but because they did not seek it in a right manner, they sunk down to a greater distance, and fell into such great errors, that they did not even possess common wisdom.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:7
verses.text: For they were not only unwilling to maintain religion, but they even took it away; while, led on by the appearance of false virtue, they endeavour to free the mind from all fear: and this overturning of religion gains the name of nature.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:8
verses.text: For they, either being ignorant by whom the world was made, or wishing to persuade men that nothing was completed by divine intelligence, said that nature was the mother of all things, as though they should say that all things were produced of their own accord: by which word they altogether confess their own ignorance.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:9
verses.text: For nature, apart from divine providence and power, is absolutely nothing.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:10
verses.text: But if they call God nature, what perverseness is it, to use the name of nature rather than of God! But if nature is the plan, or necessity, or condition of birth, it is not by itself capable of sensation; but there must necessarily be a divine mind, which by its foresight furnishes the beginning of their existence to all things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:11
verses.text: Or if nature is heaven and earth, and everything which is created, nature is not God, but the work of God.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:12
verses.text: By a similar error they believe in the existence of fortune, as a goddess mocking the affairs of then with various casualties, because they know not from what source things good and evil happen to them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:13
verses.text: They think that they are brought together to do battle with her; nor do they assign any reason by whom and on what account they are thus matched; but they only boast that they are every moment carrying on a contest for life and death with fortune.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:14
verses.text: Now, as many as have consoled any persons on account of the death and removal of friends, have censured the name of fortune with the most severe accusations; nor is there any disputation of theirs on the subject of virtue, in which fortune is not harassed.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:15
verses.text: M.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:16
verses.text: Tullius, in his Consolation, says that he has always fought against fortune, and that she was always overpowered by him when he had valiantly beaten back the attacks of his enemies; that he was not subdued by her even then, when he was driven from his home and deprived of his country; but then, when he lost his dearest daughter, he shamefully confesses that he is overcome by fortune.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:17
verses.text: I yield, he says, and raise my hand.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:18
verses.text: What is more wretched than this man, who thus lies prostrate? He acts foolishly, he says; but it is one who professes that he is wise.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:19
verses.text: What, then, does the assumption of the name imply? What that contempt of things which is laid claim to with magnificent words? What that dress, so different from others? Or why do you give precepts of wisdom at all, if no one has yet been found who is wise? And does any one bear ill-will to us because we deny that philosophers are wise, when they themselves confess that they neither have knowledge nor wisdom? For if at any time they have so failed that they are not even able to feign anything, as their practice is in other cases, then in truth they are reminded of their ignorance; and, as though in madness, they spring up and exclaim that they are blind and foolish.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:20
verses.text: Anaxagoras pronounces that all things are overspread with darkness.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:21
verses.text: Empedocles complains that the paths of the senses are narrow, as though for his reflections he had need of a chariot and four horses.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:22
verses.text: Democritus says that the truth lies sunk in a well so deep that it has no bottom; foolishly, indeed, as he says other things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:23
verses.text: For the truth is not, as it were, sunk in a well to which it was permitted him to descend, or even to fall, but, as it were, placed on the highest top of a lofty mountain, or in heaven, which is most true.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:24
verses.text: For what reason is there why he should say that it is sunk below rather than that it is raised aloft? unless by chance he preferred to place the mind also in the feet, or in the bottom of the heels, rather than in the breast or in the head.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:25
verses.text: So widely removed were they from the truth itself, that even the posture of their own body did not admonish them, that the truth must be sought for by them in the highest place.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:26
verses.text: From this despair arose that confession of Socrates, in which he said that he knew nothing but this one thing alone, that he knew nothing.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:27
verses.text: From this flowed the system of the Academy, if that is to be called a system in which ignorance is both learnt and taught.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:28
verses.text: But not even those who claimed for themselves knowledge were able consistently to defend that very thing which they thought that they knew.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:29
verses.text: For since they were not in agreement with one another, through their ignorance of divine things they were so inconsistent and uncertain, and often asserting things contrary to one another, that you are unable to determine and decide what their meaning was.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:30
verses.text: Why therefore should you fight against those men who perish by their own sword? Why should you labour to refute those whom their own speech refutes and presses? Aristotle, says Cicero, accusing the ancient philosophers, declares that they are either most foolish or most vainglorious, since they thought that philosophy was perfected by their talents; but that he saw, because a great addition had been made in a few years, that philosophy would be complete in a short time.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:31
verses.text: What, then, was that time? In what manner, when, or by whom, was philosophy completed? For that which he said, that they were most foolish in supposing that philosophy was made perfect by their talents, is true; but he did not even himself speak with sufficient discretion, who thought that it had either been begun by the ancients, or increased by those who were more recent, or that it would shortly be brought to perfection by those of later times.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 28:32
verses.text: For that can never be investigated which is not sought by its own way.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:2
verses.text: XXIX.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:3
verses.text: —Of Fortune Again, and Virtue.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:4
verses.text: But let us return to the subject which we laid aside.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:5
verses.text: Fortune, therefore, by itself, is nothing; nor must we so regard it as though it had any perception, since fortune is the sudden and unexpected occurrence of accidents.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:6
verses.text: But philosophers, that they may not sometimes fail to err, wish to be wise in a foolish matter; and say that she is not a goddess, as is generally believed, but a god.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:7
verses.text: Sometimes, however, they call this god nature, sometimes fortune, "because he brings about," says the same Cicero, "many things unexpected by us, on account of our want of intelligence and our ignorance of causes".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:8
verses.text: Since, therefore, they are ignorant of the causes on account of which anything is done, they must also be ignorant of him who does them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:9
verses.text: The same writer, in a work of great seriousness, in which he was giving to his son precepts of life drawn from philosophy, says, "Who can be ignorant that the power of fortune is great on either side? For both when we meet with a prosperous breeze from her we gain the issues which we desire, and when she has breathed contrary to us we are dashed on the rocks".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:10
verses.text: First of all, he who says that nothing can be known, spoke this as though he himself and all men had knowledge.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:11
verses.text: Then he who endeavours to render doubtful even the things which are plain, thought that this was plain, which ought to have been to him especially doubtful; for to a wise man it is altogether false.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:12
verses.text: Who, he says, knows not? I indeed know not.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:13
verses.text: Let him teach me, if he can, what that power is, what that breeze, and what the contrary breath.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:14
verses.text: It is disgraceful, therefore, for a man of talent to say that, which if you were to deny it, he would be unable to prove.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:15
verses.text: Lastly, he who says that the assent must be withheld because it is the part of a foolish man rashly to assent to things which are unknown to him, he, I say, altogether believed the opinions of the vulgar and uninstructed, who think that it is fortune which gives to men good and evil things.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:16
verses.text: For they represent her image with the horn of plenty and with a rudder, as though she both gave wealth and had the government of human affairs.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:17
verses.text: And to this opinion Virgil assented, who calls fortune omnipotent; and the historian who says, But assuredly fortune bears sway in everything.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:18
verses.text: What place, then, remains for the other gods? Why is she not said to reign by herself, if she has more power than others; or why is she not alone worshipped, if she has power in all things? Or if she inflicts evils only, let them bring forward some cause why, if she is a goddess, she envies men, and desires their destruction, though she is religiously worshipped by them; why she is more favourable to the wicked and more unfavourable to the good; why she plots, afflicts, deceives, exterminates; who appointed her as the perpetual harasser of the race of men; why, in short, she has obtained so mischievous a power, that she renders all things illustrious or obscure according to her caprice rather than in accordance with the truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:19
verses.text: Philosophers, I say, ought rather to have inquired into these things, than rashly to have accused fortune, who is innocent: for although she has some existence, yet no reason can be brought forward by them why she should be as hostile to men as she is supposed to be.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:20
verses.text: Therefore all those speeches in which they rail at the injustice of fortune, and in opposition to fortune arrogantly boast of their own virtues, are nothing else but the ravings of thoughtless levity.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:21
verses.text: Wherefore let them not envy us, to whom God has revealed the truth: who, as we know that fortune is nothing, so also know that there is a wicked and crafty spirit who is unfriendly to the good, and the enemy of righteousness, who acts in opposition to God; the cause of whose enmity we have explained in the second book.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:22
verses.text: He therefore lays plots against all; but those who are ignorant of God he hinders by error, he overwhelms with folly, he overspreads with darkness, that no one may be able to attain to the knowledge of the divine name, in which alone are contained both wisdom and everlasting life.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:23
verses.text: Those, on the other hand, who know God, he assails with wiles and craft, that he may ensnare them with desire and lust, and when they are corrupted by the blandishments of sin, may impel them to death; or, if he shall have not succeeded by stratagem, he attempts to cast them down by force and violence.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:24
verses.text: For on this account he was not at once thrust down by God to punishment at the original transgression, that by his malice he may exercise man to virtue: for unless this is in constant agitation, unless it is strengthened by continual harassing, it cannot be perfect, inasmuch as virtue is dauntless and unconquered patience in enduring evils.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:25
verses.text: From which it comes to pass that there is no virtue if an adversary is wanting.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:26
verses.text: When, therefore, they perceived the force of this perverse power opposed to virtue, and were ignorant of its name, they invented for themselves the senseless name of fortune; and how far this is removed from wisdom, Juvenal declares in these verses:—  "No divine power is absent if there is prudence; but we make you a goddess, O Fortune, and place you in heaven".

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:27
verses.text: It was folly, therefore, and error, and blindness, and, as Cicero says, ignorance of facts and causes, which introduced the names of Nature and Fortune.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:28
verses.text: But as they are ignorant of their adversary, so also they do not indeed know virtue the knowledge of which is derived from the idea of an adversary.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:29
verses.text: And if this is joined with wisdom, or, as they say, is itself also wisdom, they must be ignorant in what subjects it is contained.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:30
verses.text: For no one can possibly be furnished with true arms if he is ignorant of the enemy against whom he must be armed; nor can he overcome his adversary, who in fighting does not attack his real enemy, but a shadow.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 29:31
verses.text: For he will be overthrown, who, having his attention fixed on another object, shall not previously have foreseen or guarded against the blow aimed at his vitals.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:1
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:2
verses.text: XXX.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:3
verses.text: —The Conclusion of the Things Before Spoken; And by What Means We Must Pass from the Vanity of the Philosophers to True Wisdom, and the Knowledge of the True God, in Which Alone are Virtue and Happiness.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:4
verses.text: I have taught, as far as my humble talents permitted, that the philosophers held a course widely deviating from the truth.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:5
verses.text: I perceive, however, how many things I have omitted, because it was not my province to enter into a disputation against philosophers.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:6
verses.text: But it was necessary for me to make a digression to this subject, that I might show that so many and great intellects have expended themselves in vain on false subjects, lest any one by chance being shut out by corrupt superstitions, should wish to betake himself to them as though about to find some certainty.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:7
verses.text: Therefore the only hope, the only safety for man, is placed in this doctrine, which we defend.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:8
verses.text: All the wisdom of man consists in this alone, the knowledge and worship of God: this is our tenet, this our opinion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:9
verses.text: Therefore with all the power of my voice I testify, I proclaim, I declare: Here, here is that which all philosophers have sought throughout their whole life; and yet, they have not been able to investigate, to grasp, and to attain to it, because they either retained a religion which was corrupt, or took it away altogether.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:10
verses.text: Let them therefore all depart, who do not instruct human life, but throw it into confusion.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:11
verses.text: For what do they teach? or whom do they instruct, who have not yet instructed themselves? whom are the sick able to heal, whom can the blind guide? Let us all, therefore, who have any regard for wisdom, betake ourselves to this subject.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:12
verses.text: Or shall we wait until Socrates knows something? or Anaxagoras finds light in the darkness? or until Democritus draws forth truth from the well? or Empedocles extends the paths of his soul? or until Arcesilas and Carneades see, and feel, and perceive?  Lo, a voice from heaven teaching the truth, and displaying to us a light brighter than the sun itself.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:13
verses.text: Why are we unjust to ourselves, and delay to take up wisdom, which learned men, though they wasted their lives in its pursuit, were never able to discover.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:14
verses.text: Let him who wishes to be wise and happy hear the voice of God, learn righteousness, understand the mystery of his birth, despise human affairs, embrace divine things, that he may gain that chief good to which he was born.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:15
verses.text: Having overthrown all false religions, and having refuted all the arguments, as many as it was customary or possible to bring forward in their defence; then, having proved the systems of philosophy to be false, we must now come to true religion and wisdom, since, as I shall teach, they are both connected together; that we may maintain it either by arguments, or by examples, or by competent witnesses, and may show that the folly with which those worshippers of gods do not cease to upbraid us, has no existence with us, but lies altogether with them.

verses.name: Lactantius: Divine Institutes Book III 30:16
verses.text: And although, in the former books, when I was contending against false religions, and in this, when I was overthrowing false wisdom, I showed where the truth is, yet the next book will more plainly indicate what is true religion and what true wisdom.
